@pearkes @xvrmdf My issue with this is not a tracking error. It's a question of more-liquid bonds underperforming less-liquid bonds by a widening margin over time. This makes total sense; you have ETFs that are forced to buy high and sell low.

@pearkes @xvrmdf Right now you're seeing market repricings of certain securities. It arguably wouldn't be as easy for HY investors to demand these repricings lower if it weren't for forced selling from the ETFs

Looking at credit markets, there isn't a sense of panic there. HYG actually saw inflows yesterday. The rise in yields was relatively tame compared with stocks. But there's been a shift in tone that's important. (1/3)

We've gone from everything is generally positive for credit, to everything is leaning more negative. Higher inflation means higher yields which introduces refinancing costs. A selloff in stocks causes spreads to widen. (2/3)

While this selloff isn't the end of the world, it highlights a turning point for the narrative. We've gone from goldilocks to maybe not-quite-goldilocks, which means it'll probably be a much rockier year in credit than the placid backdrop many have grown accustomed to. (3/3)

This is a confusing jobs report. US employers added the most workers since mid-2016, but hourly wages didn't increase as much as analysts had expected. Bond traders are generally taking this to be positive for growth, with yields ticking up, but the inflation conundrum remains.

@markbspiegel But why now? At this stage of the expansion? Employers have been saying for a while that they can't find enough qualified workers. Suddenly they can find them without paying them more? Something seems off

@suvyboy It is for the consumer, and it can be for the economy if inflation stays positive at a slow, steady pace. But if it starts to slow or even go negative, the government & companies that have packed on tons of debt are going to have a serious problem.

@markbspiegel Seems so, it's just odd that they're coming into the workforce now, without higher wages, without a massive wave of new training programs.... There could be a great explanation. I just found it somewhat perplexing. Thanks for the back and forth.

@PatCDev This is important. Healthcare, rent & childcare costs have increased substantially, but wages haven't kept up. So perhaps Tshirts and Cokes are the same price as they were years ago, but most consumers are still being crimped. Without wages going up, this is a concerning backdrop
@aRishisays This is interesting, thanks

@DavidSchawel There has been a disproportionate amount of BBB issuance... not saying that there's going to be a huge blow up, but certainly it's something to take into account when looking at spreads historically vs now. They ought to be wider on a credit rating basis, even historically

This is a good post. https://t.co/iWlJC2U43s But the rise in U.S. consumer debt does raise a question: is the average American in a worse position than the economy may suggest? Especially when paired with the tick up in delinquencies & defaults?

Seems unlikely for the current US consumer debt load to spur another crisis like the one in 2008. But there's a different set of problems here, where the middle-class is renting more, buying fewer homes, & borrowing substantially more money for everything from cars to education.
The consequence of this will be highly damaging in a downturn, both economically and socially, when more people fail to pay their debts, get evicted from their rental properties, etc etc.
@evan_lorenz YES. "Discretionary income" is a fungible concept. Does it include healthcare costs? Rent? Education? Car insurance? Those are the charges that have been increasing fastest.

@Joe_Parisi Sure, although often rent isn't included as "debt" when looking at debt to income ratios. But it's a fixed cost and has been increasing at a faster pace than wages, which is why traditional consumer leverage metrics may understate the stress

@Joe_Parisi true, & certainly there isn't leverage upon leverage w/today's consumer debt the way their was with SIVs, CDOs, etc. This is why it's hard to see another 2008 style crisis stemming from consumer debt. It seems like a more insidious, slow-burning problem, especially as rates rise

@hockeypuck2515 Good question. One of my biggest worries is a good year for both credit & duration this year, which seems increasingly likely to me. The reason why this is concerning is that it will burn the bears once again & breed complete complacency. (1)

@hockeypuck2515 It will leave the market with more excess as we get closer to a true economic downturn. We're seeing that with more M&A, cov-lite debt issuance, big banks pushing further into riskier consumer credit, more auto loan origination despite weak credit performance, etc. (2)

@hockeypuck2515 Then, when we get closer to a real economic downturn, maybe late 2019, the excesses have grown, investors are incredibly used to low rates, despite the Fed's hiking cycle, & the U.S. deficit has grown. (3)

@hockeypuck2515 With growth slowing, the US deepens the deficit further to support the economy, at the same time that investors back away from big, overleveraged companies. In that scenario, the U.S. becomes less creditworthy & rates rise in tandem with higher credit spreads. (4)

@hockeypuck2515 This would be a less acute downturn than 2008, but one that'll be much harder to recover from in my opinion. It would deepen the wealth divide even more, spurring more animosity, populism, etc. And it seems relatively likely. (5)
@hockeypuck2515 Aside from nuclear war, my kids getting sick, the electric grid going down, etc., this is one of my bigger concerns right now. (end)
@hockeypuck2515 I totally agree about PE, especially since they're managing money on behalf of big pensions, etc.

BlackRock's $13 billion 1-3 Year Treasury ETF reported a nearly $1 billion outflow yesterday. I find these big flows interesting because they hint at the type of players involved in these funds. (Thread) https://t.co/g3MzzfTJF2

Certain debt ETFs have increasingly been used as trading vehicles, not longer-term investments. Big firms are using them for liquidity management and sometimes in lieu of credit-default swaps for quick, directional bets.

This is probably insignificant in a market as liquid as Treasuries, but it has implications for less-traded markets, like high-yield bonds and leveraged loans. @TFMkts has done a good job highlighting fears of an ETF liquidity death spiral in a down market.
We haven't seen that yet, & perhaps it won't ever, but the flows are getting bigger as a percentage of some of these funds' assets as more institutions get involved. It's worth watching.

@PaulGoldman1 No, but the amount of money in these funds is bigger, there are more institutions, and this whole dynamic of these ETFs being liquidity nodes hasn't been tested in a true downturn. We're getting to a new point in the business cycle, so it's worth watching this imo.

@EconomPic @mr_victor7 Here's my thinking: the research I've seen on stock buybacks shows little evidence of longer term value creation. Here's one example... (thread) https://t.co/pMkeN4o3l0
@EconomPic @mr_victor7 Stock buybacks also often end up consolidating wealth among a smaller pool of investors, who are already well off and are less likely to spend extra money they earn.

@EconomPic @mr_victor7 Wage increases, however, theoretically distribute more money through a broader and more diverse slice of the population, including many who need to spend any extra cash. This should theoretically foster a virtuous cycle of more spending, more growth, then when higher wages.

@EconomPic @mr_victor7 If these wage increases are failing to keep up with broader measures of inflation, then we're talking about something that looks more like stagflation. In that scenario, i don't see how share buybacks would help, but bigger pay increases could help mitigate some damage.
@EconomPic @mr_victor7 If they are auto reinvested, how does that help the broader economy? It just leads to higher stock prices, but not necessarily more investment

@MonorailDad As U.S. government debt yields fell to record lows in the wake of the crisis, investors who wanted more than a 0-1% return were forced to take more risk. Many saw junk bonds and stocks, etc., as the ONLY alternatives if they wanted any real yield at all. (thread)

@MonorailDad This is the so-called TINA trade - there is no alternative. But that's changing now as the Fed raises rates & inflation and growth picks up. All of a sudden, there IS an alternative in the form of government debt that's offering real yield again. (thread)

@MonorailDad So what does this do to risk appetite? Do investors start rotating money out of stocks and riskier credit and back into benchmark U.S. bonds? Will this cause a selloff in risk assets? That isn't really happening yet. But that's the big question here.

@BM_Baruch Challenge away! Agreed - stocks are appealing for investors beyond their earnings yield, especially post tax cuts. Some argue this is a flawed metric. That said, the rise in yields challenges the idea of yield-less savers scouring the earth for something that provides income.

@Quaerite_Pacem @jessefelder On a very basic level, higher oil prices leads to higher consumer prices which generally leads to higher yields. Also, typically increases in oil prices have been associated with faster global growth -- also associated with faster inflation and higher yields.

@Quaerite_Pacem @jessefelder That's very simplistic on my part - there are lots of other factors here, including the dollar among many others. And this time around is complicated by some geoplitical issues (sanctions in Iran, Libya crisis, Venezuela crisis)
@Quaerite_Pacem @jessefelder But there's been enough of a general correlation between the price of oil and traders' views on inflation over the past few years that it's worth paying attention to.

@ALWAYSCLOSINGIT I wouldn't say it's puppies and rainbows. Although I'd love some pictures of puppies and rainbows today - it's been a long week. I'm not particularly optimistic about riskier credit over the next year, to be honest. But in the near term this isn't a sky-is-falling moment.

@Ianbins I don't think this is a true meltdown. My sense is this is the start of a process of re-pricing riskier assets to a more realistic level, given the increase in short-term rates. Cash is providing an interest-bearing alternative in a way it hasn't for a decade. That's significant.

@Ianbins My main questions right now: how much are foreign investors pulling back from US credit based on the dollar hedging costs? How much are pensions de-risking - moving out of equities and into credit & rates? How much is the Fed ultimately going to allow its balance sheet to shrink?

@Ianbins These supply/demand factors will help determine whether this is a controlled deflation of relatively hot markets, or more of a crash. For now, earnings are still good in the U.S. and the employment/consumer confidence data is very strong.

@Ianbins Agreed. That said, this "re-pricing" will become a fundamental problem if companies have to refinance their debt at significantly higher rates. There are a lot of zombie companies that aren't viable with higher financing costs. So perhaps that's what investors are homing in on..
@Ianbins Or part of it anyway.
@HumbleEconomist Not panic. Agreed. Just showing some ripples after a calm (and lucrative) bunch of months for the riskiest credit.

U.S. inflation expectations are rising today in tandem with the oil rally. It's interesting to see how closely the breakeven rates are tracking crude prices - here's oil vs 2-year breakeven rates, which at one point this morning were up the most since April: https://t.co/AkFg907pFu

On one hand, analysts may say this is a more fundamental rally due to a softening of trade rhetoric. That includes oil & anything else that does well when growth accelerates. On the other, a good chunk of the crude rally stems from current & expected output cuts.
My point here is I'm wondering how much to trust breakeven rates as a gauge of true inflation & growth expectations, versus an indicator that's been mainly taking its cues from oil prices.

@Alex__Pitti There's no silver bullet. But I think it's interesting to look at a number of different indicators. For example, breakeven rates are climbing today (even for the 5-10 year period) but the 2-10s yield curve is flattening a bit. https://t.co/tg1LHGKXZi
@greed_cap Interesting. Thanks.

@Alex__Pitti That said, oil may be as good an indicator of growth expectations as anything: https://t.co/sv6TnEO0Ix I just wonder how much its price gets muddied by some complicated supply/demand dynamics.

@felixsalmon A couple of theories: if you talk with big money managers, most will say they prefer EM credit to US HY credit right now. The idea is that EM was beaten up much more in the past few years and now is more attractive than over-leveraged U.S. companies (thread)

@felixsalmon There's also a growing consensus that the dollar doesn't have that much more room to strengthen, now that it seems like the Fed appears to be closer to the end of its rate hikes. That means that EM is attractive from a currency valuation perspective as well as a credit one

@felixsalmon But I worry about these theories, because in the past when US markets ran into trouble, EM assets did even worse. I also wonder what'll happen when/if we see serious withdrawals from EM debt funds in favor of US credit that's now providing higher yields... a lot of tourists in EM

Here's an argument from @jkylebass on why Trump has more leverage over China than any other U.S. administration, & how the U.S. should use it to demand much more than a simple, cosmetic trade deal.  https://t.co/uXsfaaKi9m

While this makes sense, stocks seem to react positively to the suggestion of any deal. Risk assets will sell off if there's a sense that no deal will be struck in the near term, which is likely if the US were to demand a more comprehensive overhaul of its relationship with China.

It's hard for me to imagine Trump plowing ahead with a larger deal when a) U.S. stocks are selling off, b) businesses are complaining about a lack of certainty in terms of outlook, and c) a lack of consensus from within Trump's own inner circle, which seems to be the case

@NorthmanTrader That's a good point. The only thing: there's a good deal of support among Democrats as well as Republicans for a more comprehensive overhaul of the U.S.-China relationship. Trump has actually done some of the hard work by stirring up the pot with his tariffs, etc.

@NorthmanTrader So it's easy to see how a future administration, no matter the affiliation, would continue pushing forward with a tough agreement with China. But I agree - China has many reasons not to cave right now, and it won't be easy to push through some massive overhaul to the relationship

Here's how a full-blown trade war could ripple through the US economy beyond the direct impact. UBS analysts estimate that expanding tariffs to all imports from China would lower U.S. GDP by 75-100bp, which would cause HY spreads to rise to 700bp from less than 400bp currently.

It's hard to see how even the Fed cutting rates back down to zero could offset that sort of tightening, especially since such a move would indicate an extremely bearish view of the U.S. economy on the part of policy makers.

One of the big questions hanging over the market right now: will rate cuts help equities & risky credit? Or will the threat to economic growth have to be so great for the Fed to loosen policy that stocks & junk bonds will suffer? https://t.co/PuS7Q8Uh18

Also, companies can already borrow at very low rates. Will even lower rates prompt them to borrow more? In other words, how stimulative can rate cuts be at this point in the credit cycle, given how low borrowing costs already are?
All this to say, I'm not completely buying the argument that rate cuts will substantially prolong this credit cycle.

@John_Stepek That's a good point. But given that the economy would have to worsen for the Fed to become more accomodative, I'm not sure cuts would have the same effect on market psychology as they've had in the past.

Today's big questions revolve around the Fed's role in countering effects from trade tensions. How much can the U.S. central bank offset a slowdown spurred by tariffs? Should they even try? Unanswerable questions given how hard it is to even gauge the impact of existing tariffs.

@farnsworth_adam I don't recall putting that out there. Not an idea I've really had, especially since the pace of corporate borrowing in Europe has been relatively slow given how low yields are (the slowest EMEA HY bond issuance YTD since 2016.)
@chen_mingi For a month over month gain? It's not a blockbuster, runaway pace of wage gains, but it's something.

@JWrightStuff But at this point, given how low borrowing costs already are, what use do rate cuts have in bolstering corporate balance sheets? Corporate-debt issuance has been slowing down as these companies run out of reasons to borrow money.

@JWrightStuff If there's less demand for goods globally, or higher costs of doing business due to  tariffs, companies may have fewer reasons to invest in their operations and, as a result, fewer reasons to borrow more money.

@JWrightStuff Not only is there no playbook for the Fed countering trade-related slowdowns, but it's impossible to gauge the actual eco effects of trade tensions. This is especially the case as China re-leverages its economy to counter its slowdown.
@JWrightStuff And yet the market seems to believe that the Fed will move more aggressively in response to increased trade tensions. Trump perhaps is betting on that himself.

@farnsworth_adam It makes sense theoretically but we're not seeing signs that companies want to do that. This is especially true as stock investors pay more attention to debt-to-income ratios and have been rewarding big companies for deleveraging.

A compelling column by Lazard's Peter Orszag, re-framing the debate about whether companies betray their obligation to shareholders by diverting money to social goals, as Milton Friedman believed. https://t.co/5xLyJa56r6

@StephenFDiamond A relevant debate tho considering the push toward ESG. Not an easy answer, as Orszag concedes. There is an ultimate tension that until there's proof that ESG goals are in the best financial interest of companies, diverting money that way is going to be a hard sell to shareholders

@StephenFDiamond As I see it, this is a key challenge of ESG investing strategies: coming up with measurable ways to show they're not applying subjective and, at times, arbitrary criteria, and more importantly, that they're not at odds with fundamentals of capitalism in the shorter & long term.
@StephenFDiamond And perhaps the government or philanthropists need to provide that financial incentive. That too is tricky, but I think it's a relevant debate right now.

@JeffCoxCNBCcom @elerianm There’s a sense that the deleveraging of the biggest banks has largely prevented systemic risk from building. It’s probably true that there won’t be a sudden liquidity crisis akin to what we saw in 2008 the next go around. But there’s a more insidious risk that’s harder to fix...

@JeffCoxCNBCcom @elerianm That risk includes: zombie companies remaining in existence far past their expiration dates, taking oxygen from upstart, more viable companies; widening the gap between people who have money in stocks, bonds, etc. and those who don’t; reducing potential returns for pensions..

@JeffCoxCNBCcom @elerianm ...etc. My point is that there probably won’t be a blow up like last time around, and that seems to be what the Fed is tracking. But there are other effects that are substantial for the economy that could fall under fiscal stability & that maybe aren’t being measured as much.

@Silver_Watchdog No but that’s not the issue here. People are worried about companies going out of business in the near term and financial markets spiraling out of control, with repo and credit markets seizing up. Lowering rates won’t help much at this point

The Fed can’t cure coronavirus or induce consumers to spend. But it can play a key role in making sure financial markets keep functioning through this escalating shock to minimize long-term damage. That type of intervention isn’t rate cuts. https://t.co/wG5dn2VhDk

@ApesPants This doesn’t rule out fiscal stimulus as well. These are different issues. Making sure people can sustain themselves through this period is separate, and the realm of fiscal stimulus. Making sure financial markets don’t break down amid the wild swings is another issue.
@TopcuogluLale This QE, if that’s the form this takes, would have to go way beyond government debt for it to be effective, and even then it’s questionable and fraught with moral hazard.

@TopcuogluLale I’m thinking the first step will be adding to overnight repo operations, targeted lending if the Fed secures the authority. Not sure broad based asset purchases is politically feasible right now, let alone the most effective. The ECB and BOJ’s results are debatable at best

@KAGMAM @RudyHavenstein @cnbcworld Not looking for the Fed to act. Just thinking about what the Fed *could* do at this point. Rate cuts and asset purchases of the traditional sort would do nothing much. It would have to be stabilizing repo markets and targeted lending.

@KAGMAM @RudyHavenstein @cnbcworld And even QE that involves non Treasury assets would be of debatable efficacy. https://t.co/WCa7vSwmI8 if the Fed bought more treasuries that would probably actually hurt at this point. https://t.co/abjjVivIpW
@RudyHavenstein @KAGMAM @cnbcworld And looking at BOJ and ECB.... not sure I have a lot of faith in that approach. Figuring out how to ease short-term repo market strains seems more feasible...

@RudyHavenstein @KAGMAM @cnbcworld My point talking about the Fed is that anyone looking for intervention should be looking for the systemic nodes of strain emerging in the functioning of the market, not how much lower borrowing costs can go

@Pgrills24 I’m not blaming the current administration for the incredible medical challenge the world is facing right now. There has been a breakdown in trust of fiscal and monetary policy authorities that culminated today. People don’t have faith that policy makers will do what’s necessary

@Pgrills24 Trump’s speech was a significant part of that, since it didn’t have a lot of details among other aspects. I’m not debating one way or another the need for a travel ban, or judging the speech itself. But if you look at market action, it had a negative effect on futures right away

@Pgrills24 People are looking for a fiscal stimulus that allows companies and households to keep operating through this slowdown. They are starting to doubt they’re going to get one that’s big enough to avoid a recession. Trump’s speech was part of it, but it’s not just on him.

@1Cecilia1967 @Pgrills24 You raise a good question: is there anything that Trump could have said that would have satisfied markets? This point is debatable. I spoke with a lot of people today who said yes, but it’s a fast moving situation with a devastating short term impact.

@1Cecilia1967 @Pgrills24 That said, there were some aspects of the speech that really spooked the market. The travel ban that wasn’t clearly articulated. The misspoken mention of halting trade. The lack of details about a lending program to keep smaller business and strapped households solvent.

MS’s Mike Wilson doubles down on being bullish, saying equity & credit markets are attractive buys now on a 6-12-month horizon. “Bear markets end with recessions, they don’t begin with them, making the risk/reward more attractive today than it’s been in years.”

His note, the “Sunday start” from Morgan Stanley, is compelling. Basically he argues that the amount of money being thrown at this, particularly on the fiscal stimulus side, will lead to real inflation & a weakening of the dollar.
I’m struck by the massive gap between those who foresee significant inflation and those who expect historic deflation. There seem to be more in the deflation camp right now: https://t.co/yIC9QlYg2Z

The 2008-2009 wave of money printing didn’t stoke inflation & many believe that this time will be the same. The distinction, as MS’s Wilson puts it, is that this time we’re getting a significant fiscal stimulus. Still, the consensus appears to be deflation.

@ClausVistesen This raises a huge question for the Fed: how do they respond to a sudden surge in inflation down the line? Raise rates suddenly and aggressively? Let inflation rip? And will the eventual inflation be good - ie having a strong wage inflation w/price increases - or be stagflation?

Wealth inequality worsened substantially after the 2008 crisis, but improved after the Great Depression. From 1929 to 1932, the top 0.1%’s share of all U.S. household wealth plunged by a third, and the top 0.01%’s portion fell by half: study https://t.co/bkluPfR3Dd

In contrast, from 2009 to 2012, when the economy was supposedly recovering, the earnings of the bottom 50% of Americans fell 1.5%, while the top 1%’s income rose 21%. By 2012 the top 0.1% collectively controlled a fifth of U.S. wealth, more than at any point since 1929.

Jay Powell seems to have ignited a new round of optimism among junk-bond buyers. The biggest U.S. high-yield bond ETF $HYG saw another half billion dollars flow into it yesterday, with flows also going to $JNK & even $EMB, which owns emerging-markets debt. https://t.co/q7PT2zCzlx

Fed Chair Powell did the opposite yesterday of pushing back against speculation that the central bank could buy more (and junkier) credit, or even buy stocks. Instead, he just said they could expand efforts & they're not out of ammo. Traders seem to be taking this as risk on.

It's helpful to remember that the Fed has yet to buy a single junk bond. This is all communication. The central bank has managed to put a floor under borrowing costs for many companies without putting a dollar to work. If it can continue to do this, it won't need to buy anything.

The one (major) caveat to this is what happens when some of these businesses still can't survive, even with additional funding at relatively low costs. What happens then, especially if insolvencies become systemic, as Citi's Matt King was discussing recently.

My final thought on this: Jay Powell will look like a genius if this is a shorter disruption & the US can get back to work relatively quickly. If that's not the case, he'll face a lot of questioning about pushing investors deeper into risk before a massive surge in bankruptcies.

Here's an Atlantic article about how CLOs could pose a systemic risk to the financial system. As a rebuttal, Wells Fargo's Dave Preston points out that AAA tranches typically require cumulative defaults of at least 80%-90% and loss rates of at least 40%-45% for a principal loss. https://t.co/nbJrFEoAOA

An interesting statistic from Preston's report today:  "Currently, the US CLO market is roughly $700 billion; US bank CLO holdings are roughly $115 billion...Roughly 80% of US bank CLO exposure is held by 3 large banks, representing 1-2% of each respective bank’s total assets."

I'm sympathetic to the idea that losses may be greater among CLOs this cycle than last, when they were pretty resilient. But to conflate the size of the cash CDO mkt with the current CLO mkt seems to disregard the amount of leverage - CDO-squareds, synthetic CDOs - last time.
